page.paragraph: Listen to a conversation between a student and a professor.
Hello, Dr. Hart, do you have a moment? I'd like to ask you a question if I could.
Now's just fine. What's your question?
Well, I didn't do very well on the last exam, the one on the structure of the Earth.
Do you have your exam paper with you? Let me see what you did…Um…You've got a lot of things confused here.
I do?
Yes,…for example, here you said that the Earth's crust under landmasses is thin and the crust under the oceans is thick. That's not right; it's the opposite.
You mean, the crust is thick under landmasses and thin under the oceans?
That's right.
I knew it was one or the other….
Now, look what you said about the Earth's mantle. You said that the mantle is only a small part of the crust, but that's also not true.
It's a large part of the crust?
(sighs) Yes, the mantle makes up the greatest part of the crust.
I can see why I didn't get very many points on that answer….
Uh…and here, look what you said about the core, you said the core has three parts, the outer core, the middle core, and the inner core.
And that's not correct, either?
No, it's not. There aren't three parts to the core; there are only two, the outer core and the inner core.
There's no middle core?
No, only the outer core and the inner core, as I said.
OK, I understand….
And look here, you got this wrong, too. You said that the inner core was liquid and the outer core was not.
Is that backwards, too?
Yes, that's backwards, too.
So the outer core is liquid, and the inner core isn't liquid?
That's right. Now, I think you can see why your grade wasn't very high. In fact, I'm not even sure you deserve the score you got. You'll need to do much better on the next exam.
I'll try.
You do that.
It shouldn't be too hard to do better. In fact, it would probably be difficult to do much worse.
You won't get an argument from me on that!
